questions.text: The patient was diagnosed with meningitis three days back. One day he was suddenly brought to the emergency department because of his convulsions. Choose the best answer among the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Euvolemic hyponatremia The patient is diagnosed with meningitis He was brought to the emergency department due to convulsions We can find that there is neurological involvement in his clinical presentation meningitis comes under the example of SIADH SIADH can be caused by multiple infections such as cerebral toxoplasmosis, meningitis etcetera In SIADH there is an increase in anti-diuretic hormones this will act on the v2 receptor and this will cause more reabsorption of water The total body water is increased and the total body salt is normal This is called as dilutional hyponatremia aka euvolemic hyponatremia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A hypovolemic hyponatremia Hypovolemic hyponatremia is generally seen in the cerebral salt-wasting syndrome It will result in a total body water decrease and a total body salt decrease Option: C hypervolemic hypernatremia This will be seen in cases like that of cirrhosis where there are ascites There is a reduction in the circulating fluid volume and it will decrease the gfr, which will activate the RAAS and it will cause the activation of ENAC channel increasing total body water and total body salt causing hypervolemic hyponatremia Option: D None of the above This is not possible because Option: B euvolemic hyponatremia is the answer

questions.text: The patient, 42 years old, has the following laboratory findings: Serum sodium - less than 135meq/l Urine osmolality - more than 100mosm/kg Serum osmolality- less than 280mosm/kg All of the following are possible in the patient except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ascites The laboratory findings of the patient point towards the finding of SIADH where there is Serum sodium - less than 135meq/l Urine osmolality - more than 100mosm/kg Serum osmolality- less than 280mosm/kg Among the examples of SIADH ascites is not an example because in ascites, there is a decrease in the circulating fluid volume, which will cause a decrease in GFR This will activate the RAAS and it will activate the ENAC channels It will increase the total body water and total body salt causing Hypervolemic hypernatremia is not an example of SIADH in which there is euvolemic hyponatremia

Highyeild:

,

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A Hypothyroidism Hypothyroidism is an example of SIADH where there is euvolemic hyponatremia Option: B Nausea due to anaesthetic drug In this case, there is stimulation of the release of anti-diuretic hormone, which will cause the SIADH state causing euvolemic hypernatremia Option: D Endurance sports this will also cause an increase in the total body water and the total body salt is normal representing the SIADH state causing euvolemic hypernatremia.

questions.text: A patient with the following lab findings Serum sodium - less than 128meq/l Urine osmolality - more than 120mosm/kg Serum osmolality- less than 260mosm/kg The patient was started with treatment. After the treatment, the patient was characterised by ataxia, abnormal extraocular movements and quadriparesis. What should have been done to prevent this?
questions.correct_answer: C. Slow infusion of hypertonic saline
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Slow infusion of hypertonic saline All the laboratory findings point towards the diagnosis of SIADH where there is hyponatremia For the treatment standard first-line therapy are water restriction and correction of the hyponatremia state The patient has developed q uadriparesis, ataxia and abnormal extraocular movements which point towards the diagnosis of central pontine myelinolysis, which is an acute potentially fatal neurological syndrome This happened due to the rapid correction of the hyponatremia Hyponatremia should be corrected at the rate of no more than 12 to 20 millimoles per litre of sodium per day This happens when the hypertonic solution is given rapidly in a patient in whom hyponatremia has been present for greater than 24- 48 hours To prevent this complication the hypertonic saline should be infused very slowly and this is the answer

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A Demeclocycline This drug is used in the treatment of chronic SIADH by inducing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus Option: B Conivaptan It is a non-peptide inhibitor of the anti-diuretic hormone Effectively it causes iatrogenic nephrogenic diabetes insipidus It is also used in the treatment of chronic SIADH Option:D Water restriction water restriction is the standard first-line therapy in acute SIADH

questions.text: In a patient with hypernatremia, ECF volume is normal. There is no minimum volume of maximally concentrated urine. Urine osmolality is less than 750 mOsm/d. After checking the renal response to desmopressin, urine osmolar clearance is unchanged what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus Based on the diagnostic approach to hypernatremia, after the renal response to desmopressin, the urine osmolality is unchanged. Hence it is nephrogenic diabetes mellitus because the patient is given to be having hypernatremia If the urine osmolality has been increased after the renal response to the desmopressin, then it would have been central diabetes insipidus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A Central diabetes insipidus If the urine osmolality has been increased after the renal response to the desmopressin , then it would have been central diabetes insipidus Option: B Gastrointestinal water loss In the question, it is given that there is no minimum volume of maximally concentrated urine This will exclude the option of gastrointestinal water loss Option: C Ascites Ascites is an example of a case of hyponatremia where there is hypervolemic hyponatremia, mostly seen in liver cirrhosis patients

questions.text: The patient presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He is having a Duffy skin. He was diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. All of the following can be done in the patient except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nil by mouth The patient has been presented with the altered mental status He is also a known case of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus This will point towards the diagnosis that the patient is having hypernatremia Nil by mouth is not done because it is done in case of hyponatremia and not hypernatremia In the treatment of hypernatremia, water should be ideally administered by mouth or by nasogastric tube without electrolytes

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A chlorpropamide chlorpropamide is a drug that stimulates vasopressin and it will also increase water absorption from the collecting duct and reduce serum sodium Option: B 5 percent dextrose in water Dilute hypotonic fluids like 5 per cent dextrose in water are given to decrease serum sodium at 0.5 millimoles per litre or 12 millimoles per 24 hours Option: D NSAIDs The patient, in question, it is given that the patient is diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus Hence non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs have been used to treat polyurea associated with NDI This works by reducing the negative effect of intra-renal prostaglandin on urine concentrating mechanism.
